text.front:
Comparison of Metal Ion Dissolutions from Lithium Ion
Battery Cathodes
W. Choi * and A. Manthiram ** ,z
Materials Science and Engineering Program, The University of Texas at Austin, Austin, Texas 78712, USA
With an aim to develop a better understanding of the capacity fade mechanisms of manganese spinel oxide cathodes, the amount
of metal ion dissolution from various lithium ion battery cathodes layered, orthorhombic LiMnO 2 , 4 V spinel, 5 V spinel, and
olivine is compared. Orthorhombic LiMnO 2 , layered LiMn 0.8 Cr 0.2 O 2 , and spinel LiMn 2 O 4 containing Mn 3+ exhibit much higher
amounts of manganese dissolution irrespective of the structure compared to the total transition metal ion dissolution found from
cathodes containing Mn 4+ , such as layered LiNi 1/3 Mn 1/3 Co 1/3 O 2 and 5 V spinel LiMn 1.5 Ni 0.5 O 4 or from layered LiCoO 2 and
olivine LiFePO 4 . However, the manganese dissolution from the Mn 3+ -containing spinel oxides could be lowered significantly to
the levels found from LiCoO 2 , LiFePO 4 , and LiMn 1.5 Ni 0.5 O 4 by appropriate cationic and anionic fluorine substitutions,
which leads to excellent capacity retention at elevated temperatures. For example, LiMn 1.85 Li 0.075 Ni 0.075 O 4 and
LiMn 1.85 Li 0.075 Ni 0.075 O 3.94 F 0.06 exhibit manganese dissolutions of 1.5 and 1.1%, respectively, compared to 3.2% for LiMn 2 O 4 .
Furthermore, manganese dissolution is found to bear a clear relationship to the lattice parameter difference a between the two
cubic phases formed during the charge–discharge process; Mn dissolution decreases with decreasing a.
© 2006 The Electrochemical Society. DOI: 10.1149/1.2219710 All rights reserved.
Manuscript submitted February 24, 2006; revised manuscript received May 16, 2006. Available electronically July 20, 2006.
text.body:
Lithium ion batteries have become attractive for portable elec-
tronic devices such as cell phones and laptop computers due to their
higher energy density compared to other rechargeable systems.
However, the high cost, toxicity, and safety issues associated with
the currently used layered LiCoO 2 cathode remain as an impediment
for employing the lithium ion battery technology for electric ve-
hicles EV and hybrid electric vehicles HEV. In this regard, spinel
LiMn 2 O 4 is appealing as Mn is inexpensive and environmentally
benign and the Mn 3+/4+ couple is chemically more stable with good
safety characteristics compared to the Co 3+/4+ couple. Also, the high
rate capability of spinel oxides makes them attractive for EV and
HEV applications.
However, LiMn 2 O 4 is plagued by severe capacity fade at el-
evated temperatures. The capacity fade has been attributed to several
mechanisms such as the formation of tetragonal Li 2 Mn 2 O 4 on the
surface due to Jahn–Teller distortion at the end of discharge, 1-3 elec-
trochemical reaction with the electrolyte at high voltages, 4,5 loss of
crystallinity during cycling, 6,7 cation mixing between the lithium
and manganese sites in the spinel lattice, 8 formation of
oxygen-deficiency, 9 formation of two cubic phases with a large dif-
ference in lattice parameter during the charge–discharge
process, 10-13 instability of the two-phase structure in the charged
state resulting in a loss of MnO to form a more stable single-phase
structure, 14-17 and manganese dissolution from the lattice into the
electrolyte due to the disproportionation of Mn 3+ into Mn 2+ and
Mn 4+  caused by trace amounts of hydrofluoric acid HF present in
the electrolyte. 18-24 Among them, manganese dissolution is generally
thought to be the most important factor causing the capacity fade.
Several approaches such as cationic substitutions, 7,11-14,17 anionic
substitutions, 25 and surface treatments 23,24,26 have been found to
suppress the capacity fade at elevated temperatures. However, a sys-
tematic, clear relationship or correlation of the electrochemical per-
formance to the amount of manganese dissolution is lacking in the
literature. With an aim to develop a better understanding of the
influence of metal ion dissolution on electrochemical properties, we
present here a comparison of the transition metal ion dissolution
from various cathode materials: layered, orthorhombic LiMnO 2 , 4 V
spinel, 5 V spinel, and olivine oxides. Also, the dependence of man-
ganese dissolution on Mn 3+ vs Mn 4+ content is investigated. Fur-
thermore, from a systematic investigation of a number of cationic
and anionic substituted spinel oxides, a correlation of manganese
dissolution to i the lattice parameter difference between the two
cubic phases formed during the charge–discharge process and ii
capacity retention are presented.
Experimental
LiCoO 2 was prepared by firing stoichiometric amounts of
Li 2 CO 3 and Co 3 O 4 at 900°C for 24 h in air. Layered
LiNi 0.5−y Mn 0.5−y Co 2y O 2 0  2y  0.58 in which Ni, Mn, and Co
exist as Ni 2+ , Mn 4+ , and Co 3+ were synthesized by firing the copre-
cipitated hydroxides of Mn, Co, and Ni with lithium hydroxide at
900°C for 24 h in air. 27 Orthorhombic LiMnO 2 and layered
LiMn 0.8 Cr 0.2 O 2 monoclinic were synthesized by firing required
amounts of Li 2 CO 3 , Mn 2 O 3 , and Cr 2 O 3 at 1000°C in N 2
atmosphere. 28 The 4 V spinel LiMn 2−y−z Li y M z O 4− F  M = Al, Ti,
Ni, and Cu oxides were synthesized by firing required amounts of
Li 2 CO 3 , Mn 2 O 3 , Al 2 O 3 , TiO 2 , NiO, CuO, and LiF at 800°C for
48 h in air. The 5 V spinel LiMn 1.5 Ni 0.5 O 4 oxide and its derivatives
in which manganese exists as Mn 4+ were synthesized by firing the
coprecipitated metal hydroxides with a required amount of lithium
hydroxide at 900°C for 12 h in air. 29 Olivine LiFePO 4 was prepared
by firing required amounts of Li 2 CO 3 , FeCH 3 COO 2 , and
NH 4 H 2 PO 4 in N 2 atmosphere first at 320°C for 3 h and then at
700°C for 10 h with an intermittent grinding.
Because fluorine is volatile at higher temperatures, the fluorine
content in the synthesized samples were calculated based on the
experimentally determined lithium content and average oxidation
state of the transition metal ions, employing charge neutrality prin-
ciple, and assuming the total anion O + F content to be 4.0. The
lithium content was determined by atomic absorption spectroscopy
AAS and the oxidation state was determined by a redox titration
involving sodium oxalate and potassium permanganate. The error
bars in the lithium content and oxidation state values are, respec-
tively, ±0.01 and ±0.02. The amount of dissolved metal ion was
assessed by soaking the sample powders 50 mg in the electrolyte
10 mL containing 1 M LiPF 6 in 1:1 ethylene carbonate EC and
diethyl carbonate DEC at 55°C for 7 days, followed by determin-
ing the amount of metal ion in the electrolyte with AAS. The error
bar in the % Mn dissolution values is ±0.1%. Chemical extraction of
lithium was carried out by stirring the LiMn 2−y−z Li y M z O 4− F  pow-
ders with an acetonitrile solution of the oxidizer NO 2 BF 4 for 2 days
under argon atmosphere, followed by washing the products with
acetonitrile and drying under vacuum. 30 Lattice parameters of the
chemically delithiated spinel oxide compositions were determined
by the Rietveld analysis of the X-ray diffraction XRD data. 31
Electrochemical data were collected between 3.5 and 4.3 V at
both room temperature and 60°C with CR2032 coin cells that were
fabricated with metallic lithium anode, 1 M LiPF 6 in EC-DEC 1:1
text.front:
* Electrochemical Society Student Member.
** Electrochemical Society Active Member.
z E-mail: rmanth@mail.utexas.edu

Journal of The Electrochemical Society, 153 9 A1760-A1764 2006
0013-4651/2006/1539/A1760/5/$20.00 © The Electrochemical Society
text.note: Downloaded 26 May 2011 to 145.64.134.242. Redistribution subject to ECS license or copyright; see http://www.ecsdl.org/terms_use.jsp
text.body:
electrolyte, Celgard polypropylene separator, and the cathodes. The
cathodes were prepared by mixing the LiMn 2−y−z Li y M z O 4− F  spi-
nel powder with 20 wt % conductive carbon and 5 wt % polytet-
rafluoroethylene PTFE binder, rolling the mixture into thin sheets,
and cutting into circular electrodes of 0.64 cm 2 area.
Results and Discussion
Table I compares the amount of transition metal ion Mn, Co, Ni,
and Fe dissolution from layered, orthorhombic LiMnO 2 , 4 V spi-
nel, 5 V spinel, and olivine oxides. The amounts of each dissolved
metal ion as well as the total dissolved transition metal ions are
expressed in % based on the sample weight. Layered LiCoO 2 that is
currently used in lithium ion cells exhibits a low cobalt dissolution
of 0.8%. The layered LiNi 0.5−y Mn 0.5−y Co 2y O 2 oxides samples 2–7
in Table I in which manganese exists as Mn 4+ exhibit a total metal
ion dissolution of 0.9–1.8% and a manganese dissolution of 0.4%.
With these low to moderate total metal ion dissolution, these layered
oxides are known to exhibit good capacity retention. 27 In contrast,
layered LiMn 0.8 Cr 0.2 O 2 sample 8 in Table I and orthorhombic
LiMnO 2 sample 9 in Table I in which manganese exists as Mn 3+
exhibit a high manganese dissolution of 2.6–3.2%. Similarly,
LiMn 2 O 4 spinel sample 10 in Table I in which manganese exists as
Mn 3.5+ shows a high manganese dissolution of 3.2%. Interestingly,
the 5 V spinels based on LiMn 1.5 Ni 0.5 O 4 samples 11–14 in Table I
in which manganese exists as Mn 4+ exhibit a much lower total metal
ion dissolution of 0.3–0.7% compared to LiMn 2 O 4 . The data reveal
that the presence of Mn 3+ leads to a significantly larger amount of
manganese dissolution compared to Mn 4+ due to the disproportion-
ation of Mn 3+ to Mn 2+ and Mn 4+ . 18 The data also confirm that the
poor elevated temperature capacity retention of LiMn 2 O 4 spinel
compared to the 5 V spinels is due to the larger degree of manga-
nese dissolution. For a comparison, the olivine LiFePO 4 also shows
a low metal ion dissolution of 0.5%.
Recognizing that the larger manganese dissolution leads to poor
capacity retention with the LiMn 2 O 4 spinel oxide, we have focused
on a systematic investigation of the amount of manganese dissolu-
tion from several cation substituted LiMn 2−y−z Li y M z O 4 oxides and
fluorine-substituted LiMn 2−y−z Li y M z O 4− F  oxyfluorides. Table II
compares the percent manganese dissolution based on both the
sample weight and the Mn weight. While the unsubstituted
LiMn 2 O 4 exhibits a high manganese dissolution of 3.2% based on
sample weight, cationic substitutions for Mn suppress the manga-
nese dissolution. However, while certain cationic substitutions such
as LiMn 1.95 Li 0.05 O 4 and LiMn 1.88 Al 0.12 O 4 suppress the manganese
dissolution only moderately to 2.7% based on sample weight,
others such
as LiMn 1.88 Li 0.06 Ni 0.03 Al 0.03 O 4
and LiMn 1.85 Li 0.075 Ni 0.075 O 4 suppress it significantly to 1.5% based
on sample weight.
It is interesting to note that there is no clear correlation
between the extent of cationic substitution and the percent
manganese dissolution. For example, LiMn 1.88 Al 0.12 O 4 and
LiMn 1.88 Li 0.06 Ni 0.03 Al 0.03 O 4 having the same degree of cationic sub-
stitution 0.12 or Mn 1.88 M 0.12  differ significantly in the amount of
manganese dissolution 2.6 vs 1.3% based on sample weight. Fur-
thermore, with a given cationic substitution, the anionic substitution
of fluorine for oxygen decreases the amount of manganese dissolu-
tion further, possibly due to a more ionic, stronger Mn–F bond
compared to the Mn–O bond and surface passivation by the
fluoride ions. For example, LiMn 1.85 Li 0.075 Ni 0.075 O 4 and
LiMn 1.85 Li 0.075 Ni 0.075 O 3.94 F 0.06 exhibit manganese dissolutions of,
respectively, 1.5 and 1.1% based on sample weight. The manga-
nese dissolution based on Mn weight in Table II also shows a trend
similar to that found based on sample weight. Although one may
suspect the particle size and surface area to influence the manganese
dissolution, all the spinel samples presented in Table II had similar
morphology, particle size 2–6 m, and crystallite size
60–85 nm as indicated by scanning electron microscopy SEM
and XRD data.
Figure 1 compares the cyclability data at 25 and 60°C of some
selected spinel oxide and oxyfluoride samples, and Table II gives the
% capacity loss after 50 cycles at 25 and 60°C. The cationic substi-
tutions in general improve the capacity retention, but some cationic
substitutions are more effective than others. For example, with the
same amount of cationic substitution 0.12, LiMn 1.88 Al 0.12 O 4 ,
LiMn 1.88 Li 0.06 Cu 0.06 O 4 , and LiMn 1.88 Li 0.06 Ni 0.03 Al 0.03 O 4 exhibit
capacity fades of, respectively, 27.2, 9.3, and 3.6% in 50
cycles at 60°C. Furthermore, with a given cationic substitution,
the fluorine substitution offers further improvement in capacity
retention.
For example,
LiMn 1.85 Li 0.075 Ni 0.075 O 4
and LiMn 1.85 Li 0.075 Ni 0.075 O 3.94 F 0.06 exhibit capacity fades of, respec-
tively, 3.2 and 2.4% in 50 cycles at 60°C. Interestingly, the capacity
fade bears a clear relationship to manganese dissolution Table II; it
decreases with decreasing amount of manganese dissolution, con-
firming the widespread belief of manganese dissolution as a capacity
fade mechanism in the literature. 18-24
In order to identify and understand the basic materials param-
eters and characteristics that may influence the degree of manganese
dissolution and capacity fade, we first correlate in Fig. 2 the initial
manganese valence in the samples to the capacity fade after
50 cycles at 60°C, % manganese dissolution, and the lattice param-

A1761
Journal of The Electrochemical Society, 153 9 A1760-A1764 2006

eter difference a between the two cubic phases formed at 1
− x  0.3–0.5 in Li 1−x Mn 2−y−z Li y M z O 4− F  during the charge–
discharge process. It is known that the manganese spinel oxides
encounter the formation of two cubic phases during the charge–
discharge process 12,16,17,32 as indicated by a clear splitting of the
reflections of, for example, Li 0.34 Mn 2 O 4 in Fig. 3. Although such a
splitting decreases with cationic and anionic substitutions as seen in
Fig. 3 for other compositions due to a smaller a, the broad peaks
could be resolved by Rietveld analysis and the lattice parameters for
the two cubic phases could be obtained. The a values thus ob-
tained are plotted against the initial Mn valence in Fig. 2c. As seen
in Fig. 2, the capacity fade, amount of manganese dissolution, and
a show a relationship to the initial manganese valence but with a

Figure 1. Comparison of the cycling performances of some selected spinel
oxides and oxyfluorides at a 25 and b 60°C at C/5 rate:  LiMn 2 O 4 ,
 LiMn 2 O 3.94 F 0.06 ,  LiMn 1.9 Ni 0.1 O 4 ,  LiMn 1.9 Ni 0.1 O 3.94 F 0.06 , b
LiMn 1.88 Al 0.12 O 4 ,  LiMn 1.88 Cu 0.06 Al 0.06 O 4 ,  LiMn 1.85 Li 0.075 Ni 0.075 O 4 ,
and  LiMn 1.85 Li 0.075 Ni 0.075 O 3.94 F 0.06 .
Figure 2. Correlation of the initial Mn valence to the a capacity loss after
50 cycles at 60°C, b amount % of manganese dissolution, and c lattice
parameter difference a between the two cubic phases formed during the
charge–discharge process of the spinel cathodes. The closed and open tri-
angles refer, respectively, to the oxide and oxyfluoride samples. The numbers
refer to the sample numbers in Table II.
A1762
Journal of The Electrochemical Society, 153 9 A1760-A1764 2006
A1762
Downloaded 26 May 2011 to 145.64.134.242. Redistribution subject to ECS license or copyright; see http://www.ecsdl.org/terms_use.jsp
significant scatter in the data points, suggesting that initial manga-
nese valence may not be the only factor influencing the capacity
retention. While samples with an initial manganese valence of
3.6+ show a low and nearly constant capacity fade, manganese
dissolution, and a, those with a manganese valence of 3.6+ show
an increase in capacity fade, manganese dissolution, and a with
decreasing manganese valence, which is in accordance with our pre-
vious finding with some oxide compositions. 13
To develop a further understanding, Fig. 4 relates the lattice pa-
rameter difference a between the two cubic phases formed during
the charge–discharge process as well as the corresponding % vol-
ume change V to the capacity fade after 50 cycles at 25°C. Figure
4 also plots the lattice parameter difference a between the fully
charged and discharged states. Clearly, the capacity fade decreases
with decreasing a, V, and a as we have found before with
some oxide compositions. 12,13 Figure 5 shows the correlation of ca-
pacity fade after 50 cycles at 60°C to the lattice parameter differ-
ence a between the two cubic phases and the amount of manga-
nese dissolution. The capacity fade decreases with decreasing a
and manganese dissolution, suggesting a relationship between a
and manganese dissolution. Figure 6 plots a vs manganese disso-
lution, and the samples with a smaller amount of manganese disso-
lution also exhibit a smaller a. This is consistent with a report by
Xia et al. 14 that the two-phase structure in the charged state results in
the loss of MnO from the lattice. The results thus demonstrate that
the capacity fade decreases with decreasing manganese dissolution,
which in turn exhibits a clear relationship to a. In this regard, the
a value may be used as a parameter to rapidly assess the capacity
retention behavior and thereby screen the spinel oxide cathode com-
positions instead of carrying out the extensive, time-consuming cy-
cling tests.
An interesting aspect in Fig. 4-6 and in Table II is the influence
of cationic and anionic substitutions in the LiMn 2 O 4 spinel lattice.
Some of the data points in Fig. 4-6 are numbered, which refer to the
sample numbers in Table II. While the unsubstituted LiMn 2 O 4 ex-
hibits a high a, manganese dissolution, and capacity fade, the cat-
ionic substitutions in general decrease them, with some substitutions
Figure 3. XRD patterns of chemically delithiated Li 1−x Mn 2−y−z Li y M z O 4− F  ,
illustrating the formation of two cubic phases.
Figure 4. Correlation of the % capacity loss found after 50 cycles at room
temperature to the lattice parameter differences a and a and the volume
change V associated with the manganese spinel cathodes. a is the maxi-
mum lattice parameter difference between the two cubic phases formed at
1 − x  0.3–0.5 in Li 1−x Mn 2−y−z Li y M z O 4− F  , V is the corresponding
volume change calculated from a, and a is the lattice parameter differ-
ence between the fully discharged and charged states of
Li 1−x Mn 2−y−z Li y M z O 4− F  . The closed and open triangles refer, respectively,
to the oxide and oxyfluoride samples. The numbers refer to the sample num-
bers in Table II.
Figure 5. Correlation of the capacity loss after 50 cycles at 60°C to the a
lattice parameter difference a between the two cubic phases formed during
the charge–discharge process and b amount of manganese dissolution for
the spinel cathodes. The closed and open triangles refer, respectively, to the
oxide and oxyfluoride spinel samples. The numbers refer to the sample num-
bers in Table II.
A1763
Journal of The Electrochemical Society, 153 9 A1760-A1764 2006
A1763
Downloaded 26 May 2011 to 145.64.134.242. Redistribution subject to ECS license or copyright; see http://www.ecsdl.org/terms_use.jsp
much more effective than others. With a given cationic substitution,
the anionic fluorine substitution decreases them further, resulting in
a superior capacity retention for cation-substituted oxyfluorides.
Conclusions
The transition metal ion dissolutions from layered, orthorhombic
LiMnO 2 , 4 V spinel, 5 V spinel, and olivine LiFePO 4 cathodes have
been investigated systematically. The cathodes containing Mn 3+ lead
to a larger amount of manganese dissolution than the total metal ion
dissolution found from cathodes containing Mn 4+ or from LiCoO 2
and LiFePO 4 . However, the amount of manganese dissolution from
the Mn 3+ -containing spinel cathodes could be reduced significantly
through cationic and anionic substitutions. The reduction of manga-
nese dissolution in such LiMn 2−y−z Li y M z O 4− F  spinels can be at-
tained through much smaller lattice parameter difference a be-
tween the two cubic phases formed during the charge–discharge
process. The reduced manganese dissolution leads to excellent ca-
pacity retention at elevated temperatures for cathode compositions
such as LiMn 2−y−z Li y M z O 4− F  . Furthermore, the manganese disso-
lution bears a relationship to the lattice parameter difference a
between the two cubic phases formed during the charge–discharge
process. The study demonstrates that reduction in the amount of
manganese dissolution and a lowering of a by appropriate cationic
and anionic substitutions may be an effective way to overcome the
difficulties of employing the manganese spinel cathodes for EV and
HEV applications.

Acknowledgment
This work was supported by the Office of FreedomCAR and
Vehicle Technologies of the U.S. Department of Energy under con-
tract no. DE-AC03-76SF00098 subcontract no. 6712770 and
Welch Foundation grant no. F-1254. The authors thank J. Choi and
T. A. Arunkumar for providing some of the oxide samples.
University of Texas at Austin assisted in meeting the publication costs of
this article.

text.body:
Figure 6. Correlation of the amount of manganese dissolution to the lattice
parameter difference a between the two cubic phases formed during the
charge–discharge process of the spinel cathodes. The closed and open tri-
angles refer, respectively, to the oxide and oxyfluoride spinel samples. The
numbers refer to the sample numbers in Table II.
text.note: A1764 Journal of The Electrochemical Society, 153 9 A1760-A1764 2006
